comments:
I've been working with E3.0-M5 for the past three days and I have experienced
a lot of errors when using CVS.  With my previous version, E2.1.0, I had no such
problems.  

  For example, when attempting to do a Override and Update on a folder several
times I received this error:

An internal error occurred during: "Performing CVS operation on <XX> resources.".
Reason:
 An internal error occurred during: "Performing CVS operation on <XX> resources.".

  I have attempted to update some of my apache jakarta projects and have
received errors like:

Problem creating folder:
/jakarta-jetspeed/src/java/org/apache/jetspeed/om/dbpsml/map.  A resource
already exists on disk
/home/greno/projects/workspace/jakarta-jetspeed/src/java/org/apache/jetspeed/om/dbpsml/map.

  I have attempted to repeat the update attempt and everytime I get an error
such as above except for a different directory.  I still haven't managed to get
a good update run.  Again everything worked fine under E2.1.0.  

  Again, multiple times while attempting to synchronize some of my projects with
the CVS repository I get this error:

An error occured while synchronizing with remote contents.
  An error occurred refreshing {0}: {1}/jakarta-jetspeed.ctma.war.jsupgradeThe
server reported an error while performing the "cvs status" command.


  For me, CVS is critical.  I haven't noticed anything else with M5 but then
again, I've been spending most of my time dealing with these CVS issues.

Gerry Reno

Typically when an internal error occurrs, additional information is writen to 
the log file. Is there anything in the log file (.metadata/.log inside your 
workspace directory)?

Actually, after a quick look at the info you provided, it appears that one of 
your files ends in a period (map.). It is possible that this is causing the 
problem. We've seen problems her before and fixed them but perhaps we've 
regressed.

Created an attachment (id=6946)
E3-M5 log showing CVS problems

Ignore my last comment about the file ending in period. It is actually the 
sentence that ends in a period (duh). 

There also appears to be several problems in the log:

Problem 1) It looks like the sync problem is due to the inabiliy to create a 
read lock on the server. The following message (and several others from the 
server) were logged in several cases:

jakarta-jetspeed.ctma.war.jsupgrade: cvs server: failed to create lock 
directory for `/var/cvsroot/jakarta-jetspeed.ctma.war' (/var/cvsroot/jakarta-
jetspeed.ctma.war/#cvs.lock): Permission denied

I don't know why this would happen in 3.0 and not in 2.1.x

Problem 2) There seems to be several errors fecthing local contents from the 
server. The following type of error appears frequently in the log:

Problem writing resource '/jakarta-jetspeed.ctma.war.jsupgrade/index.jsp'. 
Resource /jakarta-jetspeed.ctma.war.jsupgrade/index.jsp already exists

Are you using an external tool to modify resources? If not, I also noticed the 
following exception which may be related.

java.lang.RuntimeException: Illegal attempt to modify an immutable tree.
	at org.eclipse.core.internal.dtree.AbstractDataTree.handleImmutableTree
(AbstractDataTree.java:235)
...

Did you start 3.0 M5 on your existing 2.1.0 workspace? Although this should 
work, it has not been widley testing. You may want to try starting 3.0 M5 with 
a fresh workspace and see if the problems persist.

Michael,
  Come on now.  Requiring a user to start with a fresh workspace - that's not
reasonable.  I have probably 40 projects in my workspace.  I have to be able to
use a new version with my existing workspace - no option here.

After getting the lock problem a couple times, it just went away.  Almost like
it was using the wrong userid or password to try to access the repository but
then figured it out.  This problem has not reoccurred.

The other problems are persistent:

The problems where it says the resource already exists, are what is keeping me
from being able to update any of my projects from apache.  Of course the
resource exists, I'm just updating it!

I am not using any external tools to update resources.  I may check a repository
with command line CVS just to make sure I can access the repository but I do not
perform any updates or commits from command line.  And in fact I have not used
command line CVS to access the repositories that I'm having problems with here.
 Just eclipse.

The "Illegal attempt to modify an immutable tree" error is preventing me from
being able to perform Override and Update on folders.  Sometimes I can get this
to work and sometimes not.  The thing is it should work all the time!

Gerry,
  You are right that Eclipse will support 2.1.x to 3.0 migration and ideally 
we would like to support 2.1.x to any 3.0 integration or milestone build but 
unfortunately we simply do not have the manpower to test the migration for 
every integration and/or milestone build and still get anything done. In 
wouldn't surprise me if the M5 milestone had problems in this area as there 
have been major changes made since M4.

So, my goal in getting you to start with a new workspace was to determine if 
it was possibly a migration issue (and make it possible for you to work). If 
you prefer to stick with your current workspace, then we can continue to 
investigate the problem.

It appears that the resources causing problems are folders. The folders appear 
to exist in the file system and not Eclipse (hence why I asked about external 
tools). Can you perform a Refresh (avalable from the context menu of the 
Navigator or Packages Explorer) on the project in question (jakarta-jetspeed) 
and see if this allows you to perform the failing CVS operation. Also, could 
you rename the existing log file and attach any new logs that are generated. 
Thanks.

Created an attachment (id=6953)
E3-M5 log showing tests

Michael,
  Ok, I moved the log file aside and then I refreshed three projects -
jakarta-jetspeed, jakarta-pluto, and jakarta-slide.  After the refreshes I was
able to update all of these from the repository.  Don't know why the refreshes
would make a difference since everything was working just fine under 2.1.0 but
they do.  I haven't run any other tests yet but I wanted to give you this
information right away.  I looked at the log that was generated.  It is very
short.	It says it couldn't find a .project file and generated a new one.  It
should have been able to find it don't know why it would have a problem doing
this.  It would also seem that there should have been more in the log that just
this short entry.  But maybe not since there weren't any errors during the
test.  

It may be worth putting a notation in the release notes about doing a refresh
on each project when using existing workspaces.

I'm still testing and will post additional errors to the bug.

The .project error is caused by the Override and Update. Since the .project is 
not shared with the repository (I assume since its a jakarta project), the 
override and update deletes it. To avoid this problem, add ".project" to 
the .cvsignore file. If the .cvsignore file isn't in the repository, you can 
add the ".cvsignore" to the .cvsignore file so that neither file is 
overwritten on an Override and Update.

"To avoid this problem, add ".project" to the .cvsignore file,,,"

  I would think that having .project and .cvsignore in the .cvsignore file would
be the default!  Nearly all open-source projects are team shared to members
using different IDEs.  IDE control files should not be part of any project. 
Eclipse shouldn't assume that either of these files will be in any repository.

I'm still testing...

Yes, I agree. I was just pointing out that, if neither was in the repository, 
there was something you could do to avoid having the resources deleted by an 
Override and Update.

E3-M5 log showing CVS problem

  Got a read lock error on one of my projects.	I looked at the repository and
the permissions on this directory are the same as every other directory so I
don't know why the problem.  This cvs module name for this project is slightly
different from the eclipse project name (I selected this option when I set the
repository up in eclipse).  Log attached.

More on read lock error:
  I'm having users access the repository under their own cvs ids and this is
causing the problem perhaps.  When I opened up the repository to world writable
the read lock error goes away.  Trying to figure how to setup repositories this
way through eclipse but not run into this situation again.  Suggestions?

All I've done is added the following line to the CVSROOT/config file and 
ensured that the /var/lock/cvs directory is world writtable:

   LockDir=/var/lock/cvs

It appears that you did this already. If so, I don't know what else needs to 
be done.

Created an attachment (id=7012)
E3-M5 log showing CVS errors

  Ok, the native CVS repository is working good.  I tried an number of remote
cvs command line project creates, imports, updates, commits.  Everything
worked.

  I then went into Eclipse and created a new project and shared it with this
same repository.  I tried a number of things.  I first tried commit, then I
tried to do an import of a sub project and sync this with the repository, merge

any difference and then commit.  Was never able to get this to work.  I've
attached the log which shows all kinds of identifiable and internal errors
while
attempting to commit, import, update, etc.

Also, note that the imported subproject introduced a new directory 'xml' which
seemed to thoroughly confuse eclipse.

What's even more interesting is that I just took a look at the repository and
the 'xml' directory is there!  Permissions/ownership are the same as all the
other directories.

I just tried creating a project, importing a subproject that overlays a
section of the project, syncing with repository, merging, and then commit the
resulting merge which should have everything.  I do the create and commit it, I
import the subsection and then sync with the repository, I merge any differences
and then commit the result.  The problem is that when I replace with the HEAD,
which should have everything, instead I get the first commit directory structure
with overlayed content.  Directories that were part of the import are missing. 
Not good.

I've looked through the log. There are a couple entries that can be ignored 
for the purposes of the problems you've been seeing. FYI, they are:

- Some file have CR/LF line endings in the repository. This shouldn't cause 
any problems unless you are using the files with Linux tools which choke on 
CR/LF line endings.

- For some reason, the purging of stale cache entries is failing. The Java 
File#delete() method returns false if a delete fails and we report this in the 
log. I don't know why this would be happening but the problem is logged but 
otherwise ignored.

There are two entries which indicate a more serious problem which must be 
leading to the failures you are seeing.

1) The CVSSyncInfo#makeInSync method in NPEing. I suspect this indicates that 
the internal CVS data structures are corrupted somehow.

2) The ElementTree.openElementData method is failing an assert. I suspect this 
indicates a problem in the Core internal data structures. Since the CVS 
internal data structures make use of the Core data structures, this may be the 
cause of the CVS failure.

To know for sure, I would really like to try and reproduce this but need more 
information first. Could you give a description of the exact steps you took? 
Please state your actions in terms of the menu items or other operations used 
in Eclipse. Also, it's not clear to me what you mean by "importing a 
subproject that overlays a section of the project". Could you give more detail 
about this and the file structure arrangement you are using?

Ok, this is from memory now so may not be perfect but here goes:

 Attempted to:
 Set up a Simple project.
 Shared the project with my local repository.
 Import project contents from a zipfile.
 Commit to CVS.
 Import a subsection of project from filesystem selecting overwrite existing.
 (like receiving an update from an outside third-party, may contain additions
 as well as modifications)
 Update to refresh with CVS.
 Add/edit some files.
 Team | Synchronize with Repository
 Compare files and merge or Mark as Merged.
 Commit to CVS.

 Repository should now contain everything.

The file structure was just your typical java war structure.  It had about
2800 files.  I took one from production to use for testing.  I took sections of
this structure and modified some files and added a directory and used these for
the second import.

Why did you end up with conflicts (i.e. why did you need to do a mark as 
merged)? If I import a zip file over a project shared with CVS, I don't get 
any conflicts. Did the zipped file structure contains CVS folders (i.e. was it 
zipped from a project checked out from CVS)?

I don't know why there were a few conflicts.  I was hoping you might know. 
There were no CVS folders in the import.  After retrying this scenario several
times I was finally able to get both imports into the repository.  But this was
not without flaws.  There always seemed to be some type of error that forced me
to recommit or reupdate and resync until it all worked.  An IDE should never
produce these types of errors using CVS and I've never experienced these types
of errors while using CVS with other IDE's.  I should basically be able to do
just about anything with the files and the IDE should either determine that it
can perform the operation and do it or warn me (not error) about a problem and
not allow the operation.  When you get aborted operations and internal error
type messages you have no clue what state it has left the repository in.  These
should just never occur, for any reason.

There are several factors that may contribute to the errors you are seeing. 
The most relevant one is that you are using an IDE that is in the middle of a 
development effort. For many people it is still quite usable but for others, 
such as yourself, there are major problems. Being a small team, we rely on 
this type of feedback and will make every effort to reproduce any problems and 
fix them.

Another contributing factor is that we have written our own CVS client. This 
allows us to do things that other IDEs that use the CVS CLI cannot. Again, we 
rely on community feedback to ensure that our client is robust and supports 
all the scenarios and use cases that users of Eclipse require.

So, what I'm saying is that we are not taking the problems you are 
experiencing lightly. I can't promise I'll fix it until I know what the 
problem is. I have not yet been able to reproduce the problem but I will be 
spending time on it this week so hopefully I will determine what the problem 
is.

I think eclipse is a fine product and I take the time to test and report these
things because I want to help make eclipse a better IDE product.  If I might
suggest a few things.  I would create an entire automated test sequence for CVS
that tested every permutation of valid and dumb things that users could do while
using CVS.  Some examples, what if a user deletes his entire local project tree,
then creates or imports some files into the tree and then tries to update or
commit.  What is the IDE going to do?  Can it determine sensible actions to take
or allow.  What if the user has a project and tries to import selecting the
'complete structure' option and then tries to update or commit?  Or what if the
user has a project, wants to change part of the project structure and so deletes
a part of the tree, recreating it at some other location and then tries to
commit or update.  Can the IDE make sense of all of this?  It must.  The IDE
must be able to deal with all these types of scenarios without compromising the
state of the repository.  The IDE should handle, without error, anything that it
will allow a user to do.  An automated test sequence that tested not just the
'normal' perfect behaviors but tested all the possible things that users could
do I think would be a good starting point toward making things bulletproof and
insuring the integrity of eclipse CVS capabilities.

These are good suggestions for test cases. We already have a large set of 
automated tests and are adding to them daily. I will look into adding ones 
that cover the scenarios you mentioned. Unfortunately, many of the problems we 
are encountering are not due only to unanticipated scenarios but also to the 
fact that we support background operations that may run at the same time. 
Often scenarios, on their own, do not exhibit problems but may if another 
operation is running in the background. This is a bit more complicated to test 
using an automated test suite. We due run our tests with a lot of the 
background tasks enabled but this will only catch a fraction of the potential 
failure cases.

I have a similar problem using m5.  I have been using e3 since m1 and I have 
started getting these couldn't create resource because resource already exists 
errors only in m5.  I tried switching back to m4 but had the same problem so I 
am back using m5.

The other problem is that an update used to take a max of around 3 minutes.  
Now my update is taking 22 minutes and I had 3 items that were new.  

I think this has to do with decorations, I see that the decoration progress 
intermitently appears during this process.  All I know is that it is almost 
unbarably slow especially with the above errors requiring me to continually 
repreform this update.

So I tried a few more things:

Update with Eclipse #1   13 minutes
Update with Eclipse #2   23 minutes
Update with Eclipse #3   9 minutes

Full checkout using wincvs:  5 minutes

Update with Eclipse #4   internal error will attach exception

cvs update with eclipse #5:  9 Minutes, even though the cvs console says:  
ok (took 2:16.071).  It was 9 minutes from the start of team->update until the 
progress dialog disappeared.

MG, your issues, although they may be related, are different enough that they 
warrant a separate bug report. Please enter them in a separate bug. This bug 
already has quite a few comments and adding more that deviate somewhat from 
the original problem makes it very difficult to keep track of the state of the 
problem.

sorry bug 47382
hmmm problem with #s today:  bug 48348

MG, Michael asked that you open your own bug for your issues.  Please stop
contaminating this bug with uncommented stacktraces.

My two cents, then i'll shut up, this bug is already too crowded.
Michael, i have seen messages like "A resource already exists on disk..." on
windows, the last just yesterday, when you have in CVS repository two or more
resources, files or folders, with the same name but different case, that for
unix filesystem and eclipse are indeed different resources, but for win32 api's
they are one.
Even if ntfs filesystem support mixed case, when you access resources via win32
api's you cannot have two resources with same name even if of different case.
Anyhow, for what i can remember from yesterday, M5 behaved differently from
previous releases, while before i had error messages for conflicting resources,
but the checkout or update were continuing, with M5 the update stopped as soon
as it found the conflicting resource.

Gabriele, I tried checking out a project with two files of the same name with 
differing case and got the same behavior in 3.0 as I get in 2.1.2 (i.e. the 
checkout stops at the conflicting file). If you think that it should continue, 
perhaps you can enter a separate enhancement request expecially since "this 
bug is already too crowded" (to quote a previous post;-)

A summary of the problems in this bug report:

1) Assertion failures from Core: probably due to known bug in M5 that has been 
fixed for M6.

2) CVS sync information lost: porbably due to point 1.

3) Failure to delete cache entries: Now handled more gracefully

4) NPEs is makeInSync: Fixed for M6

I also can across a few performance issues related to reconnecting projects 
which I fixed as well. I'm marking this bug as fixed in M6. If you see 
problems in M6, please enter a new bug report.

traces.message: Illegal attempt to modify an immutable tree.
